instruction: A 65-year-old male with Type 2 diabetes (A1C 8.5%), hypertension (145/90 mmHg), and Stage 3 CKD (eGFR 45 mL/min/1.73m²) presents for follow-up. Current medications: metformin 1000mg BID. Develop a comprehensive treatment plan addressing all three conditions.
sol: Add SGLT2 inhibitor (empagliflozin/dapagliflozin) for renal and CV protection
Add ACE inhibitor or ARB for BP control and kidney protection
Target A1C 7.0-7.5% (individualized based on comorbidities)
Monitor eGFR, potassium, and BNP regularly
Lifestyle modifications: DASH diet, exercise, weight management
Consider statin therapy for CV risk reduction

instruction: A 58-year-old male presents with retrosternal chest pain radiating to left arm and jaw. Pain started 2 hours ago. ECG shows ST depression in leads V5-V6. Cardiac enzymes are elevated. BP 110/70, HR 88. Describe the immediate management and differential diagnosis.
sol: Diagnosis: NSTEMI (Non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction)
Immediate: Dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin + ticagrelor/clopidogrel)
Anticoagulation: Heparin or enoxaparin
High-intensity statin: Atorvastatin 80mg
Risk stratification: TIMI or GRACE score
Early invasive strategy: Cardiac catheterization within 24-48 hours
Nitroglycerin for symptom relief
Beta-blocker if hemodynamically stable
Monitor for arrhythmias and heart failure

instruction: A 72-year-old female presents with altered mental status, fever (102°F), tachycardia (HR 120), and hypotension (BP 85/55). Urinalysis shows pyuria and bacteriuria. Patient has a indwelling Foley catheter. Provide immediate management plan.
sol: Diagnosis: Urosepsis with septic shock (catheter-associated UTI)
Immediate: Remove and replace Foley catheter
Blood cultures x2 sets BEFORE antibiotics
Broad-spectrum antibiotics: Ceftriaxone 2g IV OR meropenem if multidrug-resistant risk
Fluid resuscitation: 30ml/kg crystalloid bolus
vasopressors if BP remains low after fluids (norepinephrine)
Repeat lactate in 4-6 hours to guide resuscitation
Source control: Ensure catheter replacement
Monitor: qSOFA score, urine output, mental status
Investigate: Blood cultures, urine culture, CXR to rule out other sources

instruction: A 55-year-old female with Stage III colorectal cancer post-surgery (status post colectomy). ECOG performance status 1. Discuss adjuvant chemotherapy regimen and monitoring plan.
sol: Regimen: FOLFOX (5-FU, leucovorin, oxaliplatin) or CAPOX (capecitabine, oxaliplatin)
Duration: 3-6 months based on risk factors
Pre-treatment: Genetic testing for MSI-H/dMMR status
Dose adjustments: Based on renal function, neuropathy grading
Monitoring: CBC before each cycle, neuropathy assessment
Supportive care: Antiemetics, growth factor support if needed
Surveillance: CEA levels every 3-6 months for 2 years
Imaging: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis every 6-12 months
Lifestyle: Exercise, nutrition, smoking cessation

instruction: A 22-year-old male brought in after motorcycle crash. GCS 6 (E1, V1, M4). BP 140/90, HR 110. There's a scalp laceration and deformity of right thigh. Provide immediate trauma assessment and management plan.
sol: Primary Survey (ABCDE): Airway protection (GCS 6, intubate), Breathing (check for tension pneumothorax), Circulation (stop bleeding), Disability (GCS), Exposure (log roll)
Secondary Survey with full body exam
Immediate: 2 large-bore IVs, type and cross
Imaging: FAST scan, pan-scan CT, CXR, pelvis/hip X-ray
Treat: Scalp laceration wound care, splint right femur
Monitor: Repeat GCS, vitals, urine output
Consult: Trauma surgery, orthopedics, neurosurgery
Medications: Tetanus prophylaxis, analgesia, consider TXA if within 3 hours
Admit: ICU for monitoring
